content.text: Place the masses on the rule as shown in Fig. 1.1
Place the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass at one end of the rule
The distance between the centre of the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass and the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark on the rule is \(a\)
Measure and record \(a\)
a =
Place a \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass so that its centre is distance \(a\) from the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark on the rule
Secure this mass in place using the adhesive putty. **This mass must remain in place throughout the experiment.**
Place seven \(10\mathrm{g}\) masses so that their centres are above the \(50\mathrm{cm}\) mark on the rule
Transfer \(n\) of the \(10\mathrm{g}\) masses, where \(n = 4\), from the centre of the rule onto the \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass near the end of the rule
Carefully place the rule and masses on the pivot as shown in Fig. 1.2
Adjust the position of the rule on the pivot until the rule is balanced
The distance between the pivot and the \(50 \text{cm}\) mark on the rule is \(y\)
Record \(n\) and \(y\)
n =
y =
Remove the rule from the pivot and place it on the bench
Return the \(n\) 10g masses to the 50cm mark
Change \(n\) by moving some of the \(10 \text{g}\) masses from the centre of the rule onto the \(10 \text{g}\) mass near the end of the rule and determine \(y\)
Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(n\) and \(y\)
Record your results in a table
Include values of \(\frac{1}{n}\) and \(\frac{y}{n}\) to three significant figures
Plot a graph of \(\frac{y}{n}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(\frac{1}{n}\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line
gradient =
y-intercept =

where \(P\) and \(Q\) are constants

where \(M = 10 \text{g}\) and \(R\) is the mass of the rule
Determine the value of \(R\)
In this experiment, you will investigate a balanced metre rule
You have been provided with a metre rule and some masses
Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1
The rubber band should be straight but not stretched
The distance between the ends of the rubber band is \(L_0\), as shown in Fig. 2.1
Measure and record \(L_0\)
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(L_0\). Show your working
percentage uncertainty = .........%
The width of the unstretched rubber band is \(w_0\) and its thickness is \(t\), as shown in Fig. 2.2
Measure and record \(w_0\) and \(t\)
Increase the distance between the clamps until the distance between the ends of the rubber band is approximately \(1.5L_0\)
The distance between the ends of the rubber band is \(L\)
The width of the rubber band is \(w\)
Measure and record \(L\) and \(w\)
L =
w =
Calculate \(\Delta L\) and \(\Delta w\), where \(\Delta L = L - L_0\) and \(\Delta w = w_0 - w\)
\(\Delta L =\)
\(\Delta w =\)
Justify the number of significant figures that you have given for your value of \(\Delta L\)
Increase the distance between the clamps until the distance between the ends of the rubber band is approximately \(2L_0\)
Measure and record \(L\) and \(w\)
L =
w =
Repeat (c)(ii)
\(\Delta \mathsf{L} =\)
\(\Delta \mathsf{w} =\)

where \(k\) is a constant
Using your data, calculate two values of \(k\)

It is suggested that the percentage uncertainty in the values of \(k\) is \(25\%\)
Using this uncertainty, explain whether your results support the relationship in **(e)**
The approximate force \(F\) acting on the rubber band is given by
where the Young modulus \(E\) of rubber is \(1.0 \times 10^{6} \text{N} \text{m}^{-2}\)
Use your second value of \(k\) and your value of \(\Delta w\) from **(d)** to determine a value for \(F\)
Describe **four** sources of uncertainty or limitations of the procedure for this experiment
For any uncertainties in measurement that you describe, you should state the quantity being measured and a reason for the uncertainty
In this experiment, you will investigate the properties of a rubber band
Describe **four** improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
